questions.question: Which of the following is correct about the framework of the external nose?

options.B: Upper 1 is bony and lower ½ is cartilaginous
options.C: Upper 2/3rd is bony and lower 1/3rd is cartilaginous

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the cartilaginous part of the external nose?
questions.explanation: The external nose is made up of 3 paired and 1 unpaired cartilages.Paired cartilages:• Upper lateral cartilage - From nasal bone above to alar cartilage below.292• Lower lateral (alar) cartilage - U-shaped. Lateral crus forms the ala and medial crus runs in thecolumella. Limen nasi or limen vestibuli is the junction of the upper and lower lateral cartilages.• Lesser alar (sesamoid) cartilage - multiple, above, and lateral to the alar cartilage.The septal cartilage is the only unpaired cartilage. It forms the midline of the lower 2/3rd of thedorsum of nose and supports lower 2/3rd of the dorsum of external nose.Osteocartilaginous frameworkof external noseFrontal boneNasal bonesFrontal process ofmaxillary boneUpper lateral cartilagesSeptal nasal cartilageLesser alar cartilageAccessory nasal cartilageLower lateral(alar) cartilageLateral crusMedial crusSeptal nasal cartilageAnterior nasal spine ofmaxillary boneAlar fibrofatty tissueInfraorbital foramenMedial orusLower lateral(alar) cartilage Lateral crusSeptal nasal cartilageAlar fibrofatty tissueIntermaxillary suture-

questions.question: What is the shape of the septal cartilage?
questions.explanation: Septal cartilage is a quadrilateral cartilage.

questions.question: A boxer suffered a blow to the nose. You suspect a fracture of his external nasal bones. Whichof the following will you not expect to contribute to the fracture?
questions.explanation: Sphenoid bone does not contribute to the bony part of the external nose.The bony part of the external nose consists of• Two nasal bones• Frontal process of maxilla lateral to nasal bones on each side.• Nasal process of frontal bone in the midline between 2 nasal bones.•• Nasion is the site of the junction of nasal bone with the nasal process of the frontal bone.

questions.question: Which of the following structures does not contribute to the formation of the nasal septum?
questions.explanation: Perpendicular plate of sphenoid does not contribute to the formation of the nasal septum.293

questions.question: What are the choanae also known as?
questions.explanation: The choanae are also known as posterior nares. Each nasal cavity communicates with the exterior through the anterior nares or nostril and with the nasopharynx through the posterior nares, posterior nasal aperture, or the choanae. Limen nasi, or the nasal valve, is the upper limit of the nasal vestibule on the lateral wall. It demarcates the skin-lined vestibule with the mucosa-lined nasal cavity proper. Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate. Anterior Nasal Aperture - OMARROW - Posterior Nasal Aperture/Choanae - Nasopharynx

questions.question: A patient presents with nasal congestion and the following test is performed. Which of the following does not contribute to the boundaries of the involved structure?
questions.explanation: The given image shows Cottle's test being performed and the structure involved is the nasal valve. Middle turbinate does not contribute to the boundaries of the nasal valve. In Cottle's test, the cheek of the patient is drawn laterally during quiet breathing. If this improves the airway on the test side, the test is considered to be positive. This suggests an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve causing nasal obstruction.

questions.question: Given below is the endoscopic view of the right nasal cavity. Identify the marked structure?
questions.explanation: The marked structure is the lowermost projection in the lateral wall of the nose, the inferiorturbinate. The middle turbinate (Option B) is seen as superior to it.The lateral wall of the nose contains three or sometimes four projections of variable size namelysuperior, middle, and inferior turbinates along with a corresponding meatus under eachturbinate.294The inferior turbinate is the largest turbinate and occupies the lower third of the lateral nasal wall.It is a separate bone. Middle and superior turbinates (Option C) are ethmoturbinal, part of theethmoid bone.Other important structures which could be seen in the above image are:• IT: Inferior turbinate•S: Septum,• MT: middle turbinateFrontal sinusSuperior turbinateSuperior meatusAgger nasiMiddleturbinateMiddlemeatusInferior-turbinateNasalvestibuleInferiormeatusPalatineprocess ofmaxillary boneMTSITOMARROWLateral wall of nasal cavityOMARROWSphenoethmoidalrecessOpening ofsphenoid sinusSphenoid sinusPharyngeal tonsilTorus tubariusOpening ofEustachian tubeHorizontalplate ofpalatine boneSoft palateUncinate process (Option D) is a hook-like structure running parallel to the anterior border ofbulla ethmoidalis. The posteroinferior end of the uncinate process is attached to the inferiorturbinate.The image below shows a CT image of the uncinate process.295CT scan of ostiomeatal complexOrbitMaxillarysinusEthmoidalbullaUncinateprocessMiddleturbinateMedial wall ofmaxillary sinusInferior turbinate

questions.question: Which of the following articulates with the maxilla?
questions.explanation: The inferior turbinate articulates with the nasal surface of the maxilla and the perpendicular plateof the palatine bone.The superior, middle, and supreme turbinates are present in the labyrinth of the ethmoid bone.Paranasal sinusesFrontalsinusSphenoidsinusEthmoidsinus.-Nasalcavity-Maxillary-sinusPharynx-OMARROWThe image given below shows the nasal cavity, inferior turbinate and opening of maxillary sinus.296Drainage of paranasal sinusesMiddle ethmoidal cells.Opening of frontalsinus & anteriorethmoidal cellsOpening ofnasolacrimal ductPosterior ethmoidalcells into thesuperior meatusSphenoidal sinusinto sphenoethmoidalrecess-Hiatus semilunarisOpening of maxillary sinusinto the infundibulumMARROW

questions.question: A middle-aged woman was admitted with complaints of longstanding breathing difficultiesand headaches. On evaluation, a deviated nasal septum was noted. CT image is given below.Which of the following structures is involved in this case?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and CT findings are suggestive of concha bullosa. It is thepneumatization of the middle turbinate and is one of the anatomic variations of the paranasalregion.Concha bullosa can be either unilateral or bilateral and generally occurs together with a septaldeviation to the contralateral side.In the image given below, the star-marked area is the enlarged, ballooned out middle turbinatecalled concha bullosa.297Spin: 0Tilt: -18

questions.question: In a patient with refractory posterior epistaxis, a transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation is planned. During the operation, the surgeon asks you to clip the artery at the sphenopalatine foramen. Where will you locate the site of ligation?
questions.explanation: Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) is done to control refractory posterior epistaxis by ligating the sphenopalatine artery. It emerges from the sphenopalatine foramen, which is situated at the posterior end of the middle turbinate. Branches of the sphenopalatine ganglion also emerge from the sphenopalatine foramen. It supplies most of the posterior 2/3rd of the nasal cavity. It can be anesthetized by placing a pledget of cotton soaked in anesthetic solution at the foramen. The sphenopalatine foramen is also the most common site for the origin of angiofibroma.

questions.question: Where is hiatus semilunaris present?
questions.explanation: Hiatus semilunaris is present in the middle meatus. It is a two-dimensional space bounded bybulla ethmoidalis above and uncinate process below.It opens into a three-dimensional area called infundibulum bounded by uncinate process, frontalprocess of maxilla medially, and lamina papyracea laterally. The maxillary sinus opens into lowerpart of infundibulum.298HiatussemilunarisUncinateprocessOMARROWThe image given below shows the opening of maxillary sinus-Ethmoidal bullaDrainage of paranasal sinusesMiddle ethmoidal cells.Opening of frontalsinus & anteriorethmoidal cellsOpening ofnasolacrimal ductPosterior ethmoidalcells into thesuperior meatusSphenoidal sinusinto sphenoethmoidalrecess-Hiatus semilunarisOpening of maxillary sinusinto the infundibulumMARROW

questions.question: Which of the following sinuses does not open into the middle meatus?
questions.explanation: The posterior ethmoidal sinus does not open into the middle meatus. It opens into the superiormeatus.Frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses open into middle meatus.

questions.question: Where is the ethmoidal bulla present?
questions.explanation: Ethmoidal bulla (Bulla ethmoidalis) is an ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process.299It forms the posterior boundary of the hiatus semilunaris.HiatussemilunarisUncinateprocessOMARROWEthmoidal bulla

questions.question: A 10-month-old child presents with congenital dacryocystitis and requires probing of the nasolacrimal duct to relieve the obstruction. Where will the probe emerge in the nasal cavity?
questions.explanation: The probe emerges in the inferior meatus because the opening of the nasolacrimal duct is present in the inferior meatus. The nasolacrimal duct runs downwards, backward, and laterally from the lacrimal sac and opens into the inferior meatus. It is bounded by a mucosal valve called the valve of Hasner in the inferior meatus. Note: In congenital dacryocystitis, probing of the nasolacrimal duct is done at 9-12 months of age if symptoms persist past 6 months of age and aren't relieved by local massage and topical antibiotics.

questions.question: While performing diagnostic nasal endoscopy, which of the following structures would younot see during the third pass?
questions.explanation: The third pass in diagnostic nasal endoscopy involves the examination of the middle meatus indetail. The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus, hence it will not be visualized here.Option A: Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate. Whenpneumatised and enlarged it encroaches on the frontal recess area and causes mechanicalobstruction to drainage of the frontal sinus leading to sinusitis.Option B: Atrium of the middle meatus is a shallow depression lying in front of the middleturbinate and above the nasal vestibule.Option C: Fronto-nasal duct/frontal recess is the opening of the frontal sinus into theinfundibulum.Note: In diagnostic nasal endoscopy three passes are performed -• First pass is the examination of the nasopharynx and inferior meatus.•Second pass is the examination of sphenoethmoidal recess, superior meatus, and openings ofsphenoid sinus and posterior ethmoidal cells.• Third pass is the examination of the middle meatus in detail.Lateral wall of nasal cavityFrontal sinusSuperior turbinate.Superior meatusAgger nasiMiddleturbinateMiddlemeatusInferiorturbinateNasalvestibuleInferiormeatusPalatineprocess ofmaxillary boneOMARROWSphenoethmoidalrecessOpening ofsphenoid sinusSphenoid sinusPharyngeal tonsilTorus tubariusOpening ofEustachian tubeHorizontalplate ofpalatine boneSoft palate

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about the olfactory area of the nose?

options.A: The olfactory area is known as the dangerous area of the nose
options.B: Bounded laterally by superior turbinate, medially by corresponding part of septum, above bycribriform plate of ethmoid bone
options.C: Trauma can lead to spread of infection intracranially and can cause CSF rhinorrhea
options.D: The olfactory area is very well ventilated and it aids in olfaction

questions.explanation: The olfactory area is not well ventilated, and very little air passes through the olfactory regionduring quiet inspiration. Weak odors need to be sniffed, due to the same.The upper 1/3rd of the nasal cavity forms the olfactory area which is also known as the dangerousarea of the nose. Olfactory nerve fibers pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid. Spreadof infection to the intracranial space can occur through this route. Trauma to the cribriform plate301can lead to CSF rhinorrhea.It is bounded by the following structures:•Laterally by superior turbinate• Medially by corresponding part of the septum•Superiorly by cribriform plate of the ethmoidIt is lined by olfactory epithelium.Note: The danger triangle of the face consists of the area from the corners of the mouth to thebridge of the nose. This is because retrograde infection from these areas can spread to the brain,through the venous communication (via the ophthalmic veins) between the facial vein and thecavernous sinus.OlfactorybulbPatrick J. Lynch 2006

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presented with nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea refractory to medicaltreatment. On examination, turbinates were hypertrophied. She was scheduled for vidianneurectomy. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the nerve supply of theregion?

options.A: Parasympathetic supply is from greater superficial petrosal nerve
options.B: Sympathetic supply is by upper two thoracic segments of spinal cord
options.C: Parasympathetic stimulation causes vasodilatation and sympathetic stimulation causesvasoconstriction290
options.D: Sympathetic fibres of the nerve of pterygoid canal relay in the sphenopalatine ganglion

questions.explanation: The given case scenario with rhinorrhea, nasal obstruction, and turbinate hypertrophy issuggestive of vasomotor rhinitis (VMR). Vidian neurectomy is the treatment of choice in VMRrefractory to medical treatment. The autonomic nerve supply of the nose is unstable in cases ofVMR. Sympathetic fibres of the nerve of the pterygoid canal do not relay in the sphenopalatineganglion.Nerve fibres arise fromCourseParasympathetic supplyGreater superficial petrosal nerveTravel in the nerve of pterygoid canal (Vidian nerve) to thesphenopalatine ganglionSympathetic supplyUpper two thoracic segmentsof spinal cordSuperior cervical ganglion todeep petrosal nerve to parasympathetic fibres of greater petrosal nerve - nerve of pterygoid canal302RelayFunctionParasympathetic supplyRelays in the sphenopalatineganglion before reaching nasal cavityVasodilationSympathetic supplyDoesn't relay in sphenopalatine ganglionVasoconstrictionPterygopalatineganglionSuperiorsalivatorynucleusGreaterpetrosal nerveCervicalsympatheticganglionNerve supply of noseParasympatheticLacrimal glandVidiannerveDeep petrosalnerveCarotid plexusSympatheticSensoryOMARROW

questions.question: At what site does the maxillary sinus open into the middle meatus?
questions.explanation: Maxillary sinus opens into middle meatus at the hiatus semilunaris, which is located in the medial wall of the infundibulum. Infundibulum is the space limited medially by the uncinate process and frontal process of maxilla, and laterally by the lamina papyracea. Drainage of paranasal sinuses: Middle ethmoidal cells open into the middle meatus. The opening of the frontal sinus and anterior ethmoidal cells is also into the middle meatus. The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus. Posterior ethmoidal cells open into the superior meatus. The sphenoidal sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess.
